comment: Google and their official website said they were open. Tried to order at 7.20pm but Deliveroo said "Back Soon" and Foodpanda said "Temporarily Closed".Thought it was because of ramadan so i waited until 7.40pm. However the apps still did not allow me to order and gave me the same messages as mentioned above. Tried calling this outlet but no one picked up even after a few minutes. Please sort this out

3 stars for overall experience. 4 stars for its nostalgic decor & feel and rather secluded location. My wife ordered a ribeye steak and it was flavoursome and tender, 4 stars. I ordered St. Louis half-slab Pork ribs, while the meet is tender and the sauce is tasty, it's still a far cry from the real thing that's dry rubbed. I know this may not be a fair comparison but once you had experienced the right real thing in the mid-west your expectation will not be the same again. 3.5 stars for the Pork ribs. What disappointed me a bit was that its fish n chip which has a nice beer-bartered version uses frozen dory fish fillet - good if they can provide a local fresh fish option. The staffs were friendly and provided good services. I'll come back for their steaks. By the way there's a neon sign along the main with "Best Steak in Town" message that you will not miss driving past :-)

Love this place. I've been coming here with my family since I was a kid, and they've kept the decor and great food so you can expect to be transported back to the 90's with a setting like an American diner. It's really nostalgic for me. Things get quiet at night so it feels like my secret spot.Steak is always good here, tender and done to your liking. The pasta is also above average if you prefer carbs. Order the escargots too!

Located along Jalan Kayu, Le Steak is a casual restaurant offering steaks, pastas & other entrées.On our visit to Le Steak last Sunday evening, the restaurant was relatively full - almost all seats were taken. I believe the restaurant had a recent facelift. It is decorated tastefully.The food & service during our dinner at Le Steak was just a slight bit above average - nothing too fancy.

My husband and I drove pass Le Steak several times at night and always find it to be crowded. Once, there was even a long queue out to the streets even at 8 plus. Due to this, we were quite excited to try out this place over a nice Sunday lunch. We ordered two mains: Milk fed veal spare ribs and another ribeye. I might have had a super high expectation of this place since I read a whole lot of good reviews. No complains for the milk fed veal. However, the ribeye was a tad bit disappointing. The  texture was great, but the only complain is that it was a bit too bland. A bit of salt could have brought out more flavour.  Honestly, I think Aston's (Safra Toa Poyoh) could have prepared a better piece. We also ordered the oysters, a weekend special. It was a disappointment. It definitely didn't smell or look too fresh. At one point, we were both rather hesitant to eat one or two of them. Maybe dinner might have been a better time to try rather than lunch. Maybe we happen to be there when Chef Amri wasn't around. Maybe we weren't in luck to try a better piece. Maybe, maybe..... But one thing is for sure, this place needs more consistency in their food.

Amazing food. The steak served was perfectly cooked, as per order. Portions was huge but not excessive and prices are reasonable. The steak was juicy and tender. There were no tough parts. Service was reasonable as well. Will come back.

Plum Garden is an old school family run place that brands itself as a Hakka Restaurant. Personally, I find that a little funny because they only have a tiny selection of about 10 Hakka dishes. My Hakka Father, who is not the most particular about his food, was cringing while we sampled the pork with preserved vegetables (mei cai kou rou). My family of 3 ordered 5 dishes and the bill came up to be about $40. If you're around the area and you're looking for a cheap eat, come here. If not, save the calories for something else.

This Char Kway Teow (CKT, also known as fried kway teow) is not as well-known but I would dare say, its seriously under-rated. If you're a hawker foodie, you definitely must try this stall of char kway teow. If you live near Thomson or Shunfu area, you cannot miss this stall!First of all, this is the kind of CKT that is wet, but its not as wet as the one in Marine Parade. I would say its just nice for my liking. The cockles is very chewy and fresh. I love how the cockles swim around in my mouth as I eat a mouthful of the noodles. Prices is very affordable $2.50 or $3. For $3 you get a humongous plate that makes the portions look small, but trust me, the portions are honest and enough. Oh my goodness, you can look at the lustre of the noodles and everything together in the photo. Its really that good-looking and it tastes really good! Finally, my point 'first of all' already tells it all. Try it!

I've been to Uncle Leong twice and the food is delicious. You can make a reservation easily via Chope. Crab bee hoon soup - must order! Butter crab - great with man touFried Seafood tofu - must orderSambal kang kong - very good, but ok to skipSalted egg shrimp - delicious!It can get pretty warm when the restaurant is crowded. Don't be afraid to dig into the food with your hands as there is a dedicated hand washing area where you can clean your fingers after!
We tried all the various types of crab dishes (chili crab, black pepper etc). We made the mistake of ordering wine (go for Tiger beer). You can go pick out your crab if you like

Uncle Leong Seafood is a few blocks away from the famous Melben Crab and has most of the crab dishes that Melben Crab offers but was way better. A group of six of us went for dinner at the coffee shop and ordered dishes like Crab Bee Hoon, Guiness Pork Ribs, Steamed three eggs with pork and some veggie. Each dish was mouth watering.It was my first time eating Crab Bee Hoon and the soup was unbelievable heavenly. The crab roe melted in the soup bringing out the taste of crab. The Bee Hoon which sucked the soup was just as nice eating it without soup. Other dishes was equally good especially the Guiness Pork Ribs which had beer added into it. You won't be able to really taste the beer but the sauce was thick and good. Overall, one person cost about $15 and the cost was definitely low for the fantastic food I got here.
Best chili crab! I'd come back. The fried  shrimp is excellent as well. Prices are reasonable as well. Lots of seafood to choose from.
My family's favourite go to place for crab. The crab bee hoon soup is one of the best I've ever tried.

address: 2 Park Lane Seletar Aerospace Park Singapore 798386 Singapore
comment: To be fair, we came here only because of a bad experience at Wildseed Cafe (I waited for 20 minutes, only to discover by chance that my name had been struck off).The food were generally not bad. I only would say (1) i didn't quite enjoy the crab benedict that was served cold (the crab salad part was fridge cold) (2) the breads across all 3 dishes were the same brioche toast.  maybe different bread options would be good to keep this from being so monotonous.biggest gripe was the prices.  we spent $120 for these 3 mains and 3 coffees.  Quite a hefty sum for a place that is so far out and need some form of public transport or taxi to get to.service was all youngsters who are inexperienced.

address: 2 Park Lane Seletar Aerospace Park Singapore 798386 Singapore
comment: A pretty cool location to chill and relax on a Friday afternoon with girlfriends for coffee. Then move to another spot for drinks and light bites. There's also an outdoor lawn area set up for outdoor movie screenings. I'll probably come back again to try the food as I was only here for coffee. The truffle fries topped with Parmesan cheese was pretty good since it was polished off pretty quickly by my daughter.

address: 2 Park Lane Seletar Aerospace Park Singapore 798386 Singapore
comment: This would make a nice place to chill out on Fridays after work i.e. outdoor spacious environment. Service is good. Menu ain't great with limited offerings. I had the MB2 Scotch Fillet 300 grams. Honestly, wasn't anything to shout about and definitely not what I expected for a MB2. In fact, the meat was rather stiff and given the price, I wouldn't really recommend people to come for the food. Drinks and nice place to chill out - yes.

address: 2 Park Lane Seletar Aerospace Park Singapore 798386 Singapore
comment: Ho hum food at the restored colonial buildings near Seletar airbase.Wheeler's Estate is one of four newly opened restaurants located at "The Oval", a set of restored colonial buildings formerly occupied by RAF servicemen who worked at the Seletar Airbase right up till 1971.Hipsters and instagrammers, rejoice. There is that "cool" atmosphere, with spacious surroundings, mood lighting and conservation buildings that hint of an era gone by. However the same cannot be said of the food...The menu is a little pricey, with the usual steaks, fish n chips and pastas. I went for the S$99 T-Bone and a grilled octopus starter, which I almost instantly regretted the minute it arrived on the table. It was plated immaculately, but was chewier than an eraser and definitely overcooked.The steak wasn't much better, rather bloodless and dry, without much flavor. It was placed on a gas grill (smelled of gas) and the sauces overpowered the steak. Perhaps I ordered the wrong menu items?For me, food quality comes first. I guess it's 4 stars for the atmosphere but 2 stars for the disappointing food. I'll most probably be back for a drink or dessert, but will definitely skip the food.

address: 2 Park Lane Seletar Aerospace Park Singapore 798386 Singapore
comment: The food and service were decent but the ambience at night was more like a wet market.  There was live music but the restaurant was had music which was rather annoying.  It was very crowded with lots of groups dinner.  While we were put in a quieter area it was still a noisy place for date night.   We wouldn't be coming back for dinner anytime soon.

This is a hidden gem in the Thomson and Upper Thomson area, tucked away near the Clover Park and Thomson Rise neighborhoods. Bright and happy casual ambience. Just had a perfect breakfast of toast and eggs washed down with a delicious cup of coffee. All served tastefully and lovingly with real cutlery and crockery ! Scrambled eggs were warm and moist and savored with toast and generous just right amount of butter. Friendly people and smiles all round. Great music playing softly in the background so conversations are actually possible with a good friend. Kudos to Anne and the staff here for creating such a pleasant space. Limited menu but executed to perfection.

Great ambience and place to chill right in the midst of Pemimpin housing estate. I wouldn't have known of this if not for a friend who lives close by. Post COVID-19, I met my university mates to catch up during one of our birthdays. Foodwise, they had all day breakfasts, lunch and dinner menus. The staff were nice and friendly. I ordered the chicken and mash as recommended by the staff as one of their popular mains, which I found to be a tad too salty but the mash potato was nice and creamy, balancing the saltiness of the chicken chop. Lunch set comes with iced tea for $1 so that's a good deal. The bread pudding was pretty good too.

address: 1380 Ang Mo Kio Ave 1, Bishan Park 2 Singapore 569930 Singapore
comment: I'm happy to say, their pricing seems more reasonable now, mostly under $20, except their special dishes. Portion sizes are best described as healthy, aka smallish, but honestly, that's the healthy size we should be eating anyway. Preparation quality is good. I had the pulled pork salad. Seemed like a strange combination when I first saw it, but delightful. Best healthy dish I've  had in a while.

address: 1380 Ang Mo Kio Ave 1, Bishan Park 2 Singapore 569930 Singapore
comment: Currently the only restaurant open on that side of Bishan Park, the others being closed until March for renovation, Cornerstone occupies an elevated position overlooking the car park at Bishan. They allow dogs in the outdoor area, which is a plus although the narrow layout means that you have to keep your dog under the table otherwise it can get in the way of servers and customers. We order a pulled pork sandwich and a burger. We ordered Erdinger which is available at Happy Hour prices up to 8pm. Service was friendly, although our server was a little wary of our "big" dog under the table. The service was also quick.  The pulled pork sandwich was a hit, with nice smoky flavor to the sauce. The burger was also very tasty with two small (OK, I confess to ordering the double) but thick patties. They were a little crumbly, but I was fine with this given the taste. Erdinger was the same as always. Despite a sitting outside, there was a nice breeze that kept the area cool. The canopy of greenery over that entire area should also mean that the place does not get too hot in daylight. All in all, a good experience and we would definitely return.

address: 1380 Ang Mo Kio Ave 1, Bishan Park 2 Singapore 569930 Singapore
comment: Great spot to be surrounded by the lush greenery of Bishan Park.The menu looks attractive enough for me to want to order more than one dish.Buffalo wings are yummy and they have up to 10 level of spiciness. Sour and tangy  and nicely fried. We only tried level 2. 6 wings go from $16. What I don't get is why does the price go up with the level of spiciness? Happy hour drinks till 7pm. Half pint draft erdinger for $6. There is tv screening soccer matches.Coffee is from Sg's home grown coffee roasters Nylon.Food is decent, and the space is nice. A nice spot to lounge in if you are in the area, but nothing to write home about.

address: 1380 Ang Mo Kio Ave 1, Bishan Park 2 Singapore 569930 Singapore
comment: My order of salmon pasta and sandwich tasted very very ordinary, and over priced.Entered the restaurant after looking at the weekend brunch menu displayed outside the restaurant on one Sunday afternoon, with a friend and his dog. Feeling excited to head in for some awesome brunch, the waiter told us to sit outside the restaurant (as we have a dog with us), and to my dismay, there was no brunch available - nothing that was being displayed before their entrance will be served. Must be kidding me, no brunch on a Sunday early afternoon. Ordered a salmon pasta which turned out really ordinary and paid $20 odd for it.I would sayyyy.. Next door serves really much better quality of food and the prices justifies the quality.Nay for me here.

address: 1380 Ang Mo Kio Ave 1, Bishan Park 2 Singapore 569930 Singapore
comment: I've had lunch here twice.Overall, I think Cornerstone is inoffensive. And perhaps that is its biggest hurdle in standing out amongst the crowd. If there is one signature dish in the menu, I haven't found it.Buffalo wings were okay. For additional chilli heat, you have to add more money to the wings. I feel this choice of pricing is calculating. Generally, you'd find places with these sort of levels of heat, having an ultimate level, for which if you can finish the whole plate, you get the wings free. If it had that, I wouldn't take so much offense with the penny pinching pricing. I had a level five. It was hot enough for unpleasant things to leak from my nose. Your tolerance level may be greater.The batter for the fish and chips was great. Very light. A pretty high standard for Singapore I think, but if you've had fish and chips in Scotland, it pales. The fish was a tad smelly. It wasn't the freshest of frozen fish. They do not offer vinegar and salt as an option.Lamb rack was okay. Was not overdone. Still pink. But taste-wise it was just okay. My complaint with our lamb racks here is that we seem to have only mini-lamb suppliers, there's so little meat on them.Pork ribs is served with the sauce on the side, rather than brushed on the meat. On appearance it looks leathery dry and I think brushing on the sauce would make it more succulent, or at least appear so. However, the sauce is very salty and if spread all over the ribs it gets too cloying. For lack of a better way to put this, I think the sauce is lacking originality.Oxtail pasta was boring.On the two separate times, I had fellow diners who selected the set lunch. On one set lunch, the dessert was a tiny slice of banana cake that was actually quite pleasant. Banana cake normally has a heavy handed taste of essence of banana or whatever, but this one didn't seem to have it. It could be because it was such a small slice I couldn't tell.I find that there seems to be more effort made for the dessert. In the plating of the dessert, you can see thought and effort put in. It's a pity that the dessert station isn't right at the front, near the main entrance. I think there is something promising there, but not enough to inspire me to walk from my table to the far end of this not-very-large establishment.This review particularly hard to write because it's neither exceptionally bad or exceptionally good. And so while I think I can re-visit this place for a meal, it would just be an uneventful, rather unmemorable time. I'm not sure if the location or the price warrants going out of one's way to visit.

address: 1380 Ang Mo Kio Ave 1, Bishan Park 2 Singapore 569930 Singapore
comment: A weekend hangout dine in after your walk in the park. Wings are spectacularly spicy if you're up for the game at level 10. Good ambience, friendly and attentive service. Will return for more.

address: 1380 Ang Mo Kio Ave 1, Bishan Park 2 Singapore 569930 Singapore
comment: Places where you can have coffee and sit with your furry friends are few and far between. So it was with great pleasure that my girlfriend brought me out with her dog to check out Cornerstone, located at Bishan Park. As we both have goldies (her's is more properly behaved), she decided to give it a test to see how the place would hold up. The place is decently large and we chose an al fresco area (as usual). Space really isn't an issue, but the proximity to the nearby dog run means that your pet's attention will constantly be on the lookout. We thought that we could have a bite with her pet, but unfortunately, Cornerstone isn't a place that serves pets. It's just a restaurant that's pet friendly. Which isn't a bad thing. We've since been back at least once a month to spend some time with her dog (mine is too naughty too sit still), while having coffee and I have to see it's been a great find for us.

Can't believe this place existed right in the heartlands! Great food with great prizes. Unpretentious and low key. Japanese rice bowls prepared and cooked only upon ordering. The signature aburi salmon and beef steak don were both divine! As was the champion floss and mentaiko cheese sushi. I've had better sashimi but these were generous slices and good value for money.

I am impressed ... really ... I past by this place for more than hundred times but I never came in. Today I decided to have my quick dinner here... and I ordered Salmon Aburi Don which looks like their signature. It is not only looked exactly the same as photo, but it taste good. The price is $14.90, no gst no service charge. The portion is good for ladies, but maybe too small for men. I will come here again in future to try their unagi don... it is in between cold storage and subway ... not really can be seen from the main entrance.

address: 3 Hyde Park Gate The Oval Singapore 799531 Singapore
comment: Upon entry to the restaurant, Im abit turned off by the presence of houseflies on the table in front of me. But I asked for another table & the waitress did gave me another table.Food is ok, but not fantastic. Served hot. Drinks menu more extensive than food menu.Drinks selections wide variety : beer, wine, coffee etc Would come by this place for late night drinks as it's opened till 1am.To come by for food... I will reconsider again.

address: 3 Hyde Park Gate The Oval Singapore 799531 Singapore
comment: The mussels are humongous and not fresh. Ask for ketchup and it seems they have blended both chili together. It's terrible.

Swatow Restaurant is quite a popular with the older generation and it is well known for its teochew cuisine. On friday night, the restaurant also offers teochew opera show, which is quite rare to see these days. The restaurant is located opposite the library, on top of the supermarket. Although the building is quite old, there is a small lift to the restaurant which can fit 2 persons in it. This is great as a lot of people coming to this restaurant are quite old.The restaurant is decorated in quite the old school and no frill way, with traditional opera clothes at the entrance. As the restaurant is quite popular, it is best to make reservation before coming.Today the family is coming here for the hi-tea buffet which costs $22.80++ for an adult and $16.80++ for a child. Although the family have made reservation for hi-tea buffet which usually occurs from 3pm to 5pm, we have a rude shock when the staff tells us the last order for the buffet is 3.30pm. It seems that there is an event tonight. The restaurant will be closing the buffet earlier in order to prepare for the event. I am annoyed that the staff should have called up to tell us about the problem so that we could come earlier. The buffet style here is quite different from outside. There is no buffet counter or menu for one to look at. One just picks whatever one likes from the various push carts going around the dining room. Within a short time, the table is easily filled up.Kueh Pie Tee, Shark's Fin Soup and Duck meat roll are part of the buffet, but is limited to one serving per customer. The kueh pie tee is not filled with the traditional vegetable filling. Instead it is filled with calamari salad. Interesting.For the steamed dim sum, there is items such as xiao long bao, siew mai, bean curd roll, steamed pork ribs, crystal bun, chive dumplings, vegetable dumpling, seafood dumplings, chee cheong fan with assorted fillings and chicken feet. The crystal bun has savoury rice filling in it. Tastes not bad.For buns, there is cha siew bun (BBQ pork bun), pan fried pork bun, black sesame bun and everyone's favourite Liu Sha Bao (流沙包). The Liu Sha Bao (流沙包) is uniquely green in color, and the filling really flowing out easily. The black sesame filling in the black sesame bun is a bit too sweet for me.For deep fried items, there is shrimp roll, shrimp dumplings, seafood balls, goyza, and fried durian shrimp roll. The fried durian shrimp roll is covered with deep fried noodle like crust, inside filled with rich and chunky filling. Although one cannot smell the durian in it, the taste is pretty strong in it and surprisely well with the juicy shrimp.Besides these, there is also fried ee fu mee, century egg porridge, lotus leaf rice, chilled pork in jelly, chilled cheek in jelly, baked pork pastry, deep fried fish skin with salted egg and black sesame paste. The deep fried fish skin with salted egg sauce is quite nice with the mayonnaise, although I wish that the salted egg sauce could be thicker. The black sesame paste is quite rich and flavourful. Too bad that is the only hot dessert available that day.For cold desserts, there is ice jelly, almond jelly, herbal jelly and mango jelly. The herbal jelly tastes quite bitter. The ice jelly is quite refreshing with a hint of tea taste.Overall the food is not bad with quite a huge range although mother feels the various is less than the usual dim sum menu. Although there is a lot of staff running around, it is quite difficult to get their attention. Besides the hot tea served on the table, one can also help oneself to the ice lemon tea and ice cubes at the counter. Yes most of the times we seem to be helping ourselves to the various things around. Even when the staff has a push cart full of desserts in front of us and we request that we would like some, the old staff answers that it is not for us, but the tables behind us. Funny especially everyone is having the buffet too. The staffs here seem to be choosy in serving customers. Although at the end of the meal, one feels like having gone through a very fierce battle. Feeling super drain out.

Had lunch at Swatow Seafood Restaurant in the heartland of Toa Payoh and i was pleasantly surprised.The old skool ambience of the place was really charming, with old skool ornate decorations at the reception. We ordered the prawn roe fried rice and it was really quite good. The different textures of prawn roe, crab meat and the vegetables created quite a stir in my mouth.We orderd the sharks head on the menu as it is quite an uncommon dish. It tasted really good but i felt really guilty for indulging in that dish with all the anti sharks fin campaign going around.The dim sum were good and overall it left me very satisfied. The prices are very reasonable and its alot cheaper than restaurants in town. I will definitely be back to sample the traditional Teochew dishes which I did not manage to taste this round.

Old school would be the right words for it. And this is the kinda thing I like. I went on a weekday but I was made to understand that over the weekend, the place gets packed and there are still push carts for dim sum service. We ordered a fair bit and finished all that was placed before us :) Siew Mai is my usual "standard setter" for a dim Sum place and they did their quite well. And most of their item came in 3s so it it was just nice for the company that I was with. Both their fried and steams items were good. We finished off with a big bowl of steamed mushed up yam (o ni or however you spell it) and it was great! All round good experience.

There are few things more amorous than the runny yoke of a just-poached egg cut open. The Liu Sha Bow at Swatow seafood comes a close second with its gooey filling just ready to spill out in all its sweet and savory goodness. You NEED to order it if you're here. Swatow Seafood is an unassuming dim sum place away from downtown which means reasonable prices, little to no wait (we had no wait at all on a Saturday afternoon), and the charm of the old school push-cart dim sum experience. This culminates into a very satisfying brunch experience with minimal stress so you can focus on enjoying the food. I thought everything we had was good from the standard siu mais and har gows to the century egg porridge and fried shrimp rolls. And of course end the meal with afore-mentioned Liu Sha Bow. The sweet custard is nicly balanced with the saltiness of the salted egg yolk. Such a treat!They have a buffet for high tea which looked like a great deal but our meal wasn't that much either which makes Sawtow Seafood a good value, and a tasty one at that,

Our first dinner here and ordered a few dishes. Essentially the food here is not bad (like the Braised Goose) but the price tag of the dishes is a tad too high for me to return. I can easily find similar tasty food in other restaurants that won't cost me an arm and leg. But having said that, this Swatow Restaurant has been around since way back so I guess they have their own following. Just not me in that queue then. Heh...

Don't be fool by the name ("seafood"). Swatow Seafood serves fantastic dim sum breakfast and brunches!Located in the heartlands of Singapore, this restaurant has been around for quite some time now. While the restaurant has not been advertising aggressively nor received the hype over some other star restaurant, it has been well patronised by those in-the-know. On weekends, this place is flooded with people, especially in the morning right up to noon. If you are coming as part of a large group, it is advisable to call ahead and make a reservation.While there has been a shift towards "high end" dim sum, i.e. ordering your dishes off a menu, Swatow Seafood still does it the "old fashion" way, i.e. service via a push cart. This is a nostalgic experience not to be missed (given that there isn't many such restaurants left). In addition to the old school experience, the dim sum served here is of a high standard comparable with many fine restaurants.

Went there with co-workers for Chinese New Year celebration. The service was okay, typical Chinese restaurant standard. The food wise, I love their steam crab very much. It's fresh. The fried oyster with egg is one of their signature, I like it. Will go there again with my family.
What a disappointment! As a teochew nia, I expected a lot more of the teochew dishes in a restaurant like this. The chaipo kuayteow didn't have the wok hei I loved, and hardly had any chaipo! Sigh...

We ate there 2 years ago and we were very pleased with the service, price and food. However, we went today and was extremely disappointed. The price for buffet lunch was about $27 including tax. We have 2 hours tome span to eat starting from 3pm to 5pm, however, the food was not out for us until close to 4pm. We will told to pay even before we had food on the table. The varieties were limited, in fact, we were repeatedly asked if we have to eat the same dim sum. I have seated below and air conditioner and it was dripping water on my head. When I told them about it, server just said move your chair slightly to the right. The red been soup was so sweet, is like eating sugar. A lot of their dim sum were not made by kitchen, tasted like either frozen or mass production ordered from suppliers. There were chairs & tables stacked up at the narrow hallway going to toilet. This could be a fire hazard if it by the fire exit door. The elevator was not working at first and had to ask the staff to turn it back on so that my 97 years old dad can get up to restaurant. One waitress just took a plate of dim sum from our table without asking ask just to show the next table that the dish looked like. We were discussing what is their marketing strategy to attract customers. I think they started the dim sum late so we we only have an hour to eat and therefore, won't be able to consume more. And we were provided with limited varieties of dim sum to pick, therefore, we will get sick of the same dim sum with will not consume more. All in all, their strategy is to make more money and providing less, perhaps they are struggling to survive, who knows?!?!? We will not go back there again and will not recommend others to do so. We will also inform friends and relatives who thought they were good like we did, that the standards and quality has dropped. We went there with high expectations and what we got was sub standards in terms of quality, service, quantity and we certainly did not get we deserve with such high price range. I hope the management is made aware of this so that they can work on getting the restaurant back to where it was.

My family went for the Swatow (which means Mountain Top in Teochew) Seafood Restaurant for the dim sum buffet. This place used to be Fortunate Restaurant and Lucky Restaurant before that.. so you can say it was a location where weddings and CNY reunion meals were held at when I was young. The only thing that remained the same were the toilet areas and those big curtains where they hide away the spare chairs and tables from public view. I remember playing hide and seek with my cousins there when I was young.. so it was really nostalgic. Anyway back to reviewing the food.. the way the dimsum buffet works is the trolley with piles of food and dimsum will be rolled away. Sounds reasonable but the problem lies with that. As this place is huge.. I personally feel that they are short handed.. so to the two dim sum trolleys that were going around.. it's like there's 30-40 tables waiting.. so sometimes when the trolley comes by.. it's nearly empty.. and the servers sometimes miss our table as we were seated in the middle. We noticed the chances of you getting your plate filled were higher if you were seated at the outside. Food came out one by one.. so we ended up spending a lot of time waiting for the trolleys to come by. Even the drinks were not properly organised.. if we didn't ask we wouldn't have known that we had to go to an area and get the drinks as the dim sum and the fried food were served by trolleys. Servings were depressing.. it's a buffet but the servers usually give us the exact headcount and said that she will come back again later if we should want a second helping since this is a buffet... but often the food runs out and we don't quite see the same food again. Food wise was so-so... I guess I only like the liu sha bao (salted egg yolk custard bun). That's about it.
The dim sum buffet is value for money. I wish they could change it to an ala carte system though

This is a JIU LOU. Not ninth floor. It means a proper Chinese restaurant where big dinners and feasts can be held, especially for weddings.It was also the place of my childhood.Or more accurately, the restaurant that used to be there, formed parts of my childhood. The previous tenant was Xin Fu Lou, which formed memories of piping-hot dim sum pushed around in trolleys.Swatow also has dim sum, but only in the day time and we were there for dinner.  The place was all white covers and folded napkins; sitting there I had an urge to give a $120 ang bao to a man and his wife.The Braised Slice Goose Meat in Teochew Style (~$17) was very savoury, especially the sauce. However the goose portion was too small, beneath the top few slices it was all tofu.The scallops and broccoli ($20) was fresh, but the portion was even smaller. Being hungry gluttons we ordered the oyster omelette ($8) from their Teochew Porridge just in case.Their signature Deep Fried Crispy Pig Trotter (~$25) is a must-try. The skin looked dark and the meat looked dark but it was GOOD. The skin was crispy and crunchy and yet easy on the bite. You know some crispy pork skin fried too hard until it tastes bitter and has so hard a centre it feels like biting on rocks? Not this. The meat was tender and flavourful. If you can only afford one dish, THIS IS IT. (Yes their dishes are pretty expensive IMO.)The oysters in the oyster omelette were huge and easy for me to pick out (I don't eat oysters) to give to my family members. The rest of it wasn't as starchy and gooey as I'd liked.A set of tea came with our dessert to clear our throats. I voiced out loud thinking it was syrup meant to be poured over the yam paste, asking why it wasn't poured. The affable head waiter corrected me, so yes, please don't embarrass yourself like me.I must also mention that Swatow refers to the Teochew province of China, and my heritage-proud father has claimed the food at Swatow to be quite authentically Teochew.Overall I feel the food is standard fare, and is overpriced; Swatow is evidently no Xin Fu Lou. I've heard good reviews about their dim sum buffets though.

address: 8 Sin Ming Road #01-03, Sin Ming Centre Singapore 575628 Singapore
comment: Loved this place. It has a cute, friendly vibe and absolutely delicious vegan desserts. Their ice cream is vegan, made from brown rice! They also do vegan pizzas and other Italian dishes here.I came here after dinner so was unfortunately already massively full, but I got myself a little scoop of chocolate hazelnut and it did not disappoint!I really just wish I'd had more time in Singapore to come back and try their vegan pizzas and other desserts, all of which looked incredible. Everything here is vegan, which is awesome. Staff is super friendly and they let me kick back and read a book at one of their comfy chairs long after I'd finished my ice cream.Even if you're just visiting Singapore as a tourist, if you're vegan or vegetarian or not able to eat dairy, it's definitely worth hopping on public transport to reach the Sin Ming Road area just to try this place. You will not be disappointed.

address: 8 Sin Ming Road #01-03, Sin Ming Centre Singapore 575628 Singapore
comment: I was pretty excited about this awkwardly-named eatery when I saw their menu. Ended up with the Tempeh Partay (tasty), Suka Suka Jackfruit Bowl (healthy) and a double scoop of ice cream (dark chocolate and peanut butter, delicious!) - all vegan and gluten-free. Service was exceptionally friendly and accommodating. It was noisy with conversation as the small space was full on a Sunday afternoon. The heartbreaker for me was when I went to pay and found out they only take cash and NETS! I wish this had been noted on the door or menu - typically when dining at expensive brick-and-mortar places, I assume Visa and Mastercard will be accepted, saving me the trip to an ATM for cash withdrawal. Given that they're actually producing tasty, healthy vegan food with gluten-free options, I'm still giving it four stars, but for me personally, not accepting credit cards is a dealbreaker. The location is a bit off the beaten path. Still, if you have a NETS card or are not cash-averse, Wellsmoocht is worth checking out!

address: 8 Sin Ming Road #01-03, Sin Ming Centre Singapore 575628 Singapore
comment: Brownice Ice Cream is the first dessert place in Singapore to serve low-calorie, low-GI, low-fat, vegan-friendly and dairy-free ice cream made from organic brown rice. Guilt-free ice cream at it's best. Even though it's dairy-free, you should note that the ice cream does not taste icy at all, though it also lacks the creamy taste, Brownice ice cream still holds the smooth textures.The 4 scoops of ice cream we picked were :CoconutHazelnutMatchaPeanut ButterIt might sound like alot of flavours, but they all went well together. First off, if this is your first visit to Brownice, definitely go for the coconut! There's real coconut fruit embedded in the ice cream! It is slightly creamy, with authentic coconut taste and sweetness. It goes really well with the chocolate syrup topping.The matcha wasn't too bitter, and the sweetness level was just right for me. I don't like matcha ice creams that taste too sweet or artificial. Over here, the matcha was closer to the grainy texture, as unlike the coconut, the matcha wasn't able to have a smooth aftertaste. Nevertheless, probably the best guilt-free and vegan matcha you can taste in Singapore! The peanut butter was too sweet for my liking, but you could taste real peanut butter embedded into the ice cream. Think of chunky monkey from ben and jerrys. Lots of peanuts too, that adds a crunchy bite in every scoop!The hazelnut was almost like eating nutella ice cream! It was a tad sweet, and I probably wouldn't finish a whole scoop by myself, but give me a scoop of coconut or matcha, and it will magically disappear with a spoon in my hand.The waffle here is of a crispy consistency. I would say, this is one of my most favourite waffle places in Singapore. Despite the waffle not having any fragrance or aroma. The light, airy and yet biscuit like edges makes this waffle so addictive.Overall :  A great place to get vegan ice cream, even if you're not a vegan, or trying to stay on a healthy diet. The ice creams here are great, and so are their waffles. There's free wifi too! Definitely download the Entertainer App before heading down to Brownice!

address: 8 Sin Ming Road #01-03, Sin Ming Centre Singapore 575628 Singapore
comment: I am the type of person who orders the meatlovers pizza with extra cheese and I love myself a glass of ice cold milk (don't even get me started about my milkshake fondness!). Meat and cheese are my favorite things to eat!Needless to say that when someone told me that we were going to a Vegan pizza and ice cream place I was not happy.I mean: pizza without meat and cheese? Ice cream without dairy? Me no likey! It sounded like a guaranteed one star review to me. But in the whole spirit of being open to others people opinions and tastes I tagged along, expecting to go to have a nice juicy burger and shake on my way back home. WRONG!!! This place is great and I liked the food a lot.Their pizza menu is quite extensive (much more options than the picture posted in a precious review) and since it was the four of us, we tried out 4 different ones and all of them were delicious, no kidding! Honestly, I really enjoyed it and I did not miss meat or cheese at all... Miracles do exist apparently!The crust of the pizza is the really thin and crispy and the toppings taste really fresh and unique...I really loved the ones with the monkey head mushrooms and as with regular pizza I especially enjoyed the ones with extra spice on it. In fact, the staff was nice enough to substitute and remove toppings to tailor my own personal pizza.I was not hungry anymore after all that pizza goodness but my friends wanted dessert and I by then, I was curious enough to taste the waffle and ice cream. The salted caramel vegan ice cream was delish! So I left Brownice feeling chock full and did not feel the need to eat any meat or anything at all that night.Would I return? Yes, with or without my vegan friends who introduced me to this great place.

address: 8 Sin Ming Road #01-03, Sin Ming Centre Singapore 575628 Singapore
comment: The outlet is located just off the main road of Upper Thomson and is within walking distance from the MRT station. The place is known for its vegan friendly food such as ice cream and pizza. It offers free wifi. What attracts me at the counter is the display of ice cream cakes, which I seldom see been sold as slices.I order 2 pieces which are been placed on a plate with some decorations on. So cute.Coconut-Gula Melaka "Egg" ($5.50/ mini)Coconut and gula melaka ice cream on digestive biscuit base. Delightly refreshing pairing.The ice cream is smooth with bits of the coconut flesh in it. It would be better if the flavour of the gula melaka has been stronger. The biscuit base gives it a slightly salty taste. Unique combination of the sweet and salty.Pure Hazelnut Bomb ($5.50/mini)Thick layer of hazenut ice cream on a fruit and nut chocolate base.The ice cream is very smooth and rich which kind of reminds me of peanut butter. Like this very much.Overall friendly staff with yummy desserts. There is also plain water and tissue to help yourself to at the side of the counter. Best of all the place is not crowded.

address: 8 Sin Ming Road #01-03, Sin Ming Centre Singapore 575628 Singapore
comment: I have to give major props to this ice cream shop. Competition for ice cream is fierce in the Upper Thomson area, with 4 or 5 ice cream/waffle shops all within a 5 minutes walk from each other. However, this place stands out so nicely because its 100% vegan, and they don't use processed/refined sugar, only a small amount unrefined cane sugar in their waffles and cane juice in their ice cream. I asked :) Even their waffles are vegan, using no eggs or cows milk, and yet it was still delicious. I had 2 scoops of ice cream and a waffle, and by the end of finishing everything, I wasn't like super full or bloated, but I was definitely satisfied. Less guilt, and totally satisfied. That's a pretty good feeling coming out of an ice cream shop. The service is also THE NICEST I have come across in Singapore, shocking to say since this is an ice cream shop. All smiles and super sweet. They also serve free flow alkaline water with a high ph. I don't know any other ice cream shop, let alone restaurant that serves free flow alkaline water. Do you?!

address: 8 Sin Ming Road #01-03, Sin Ming Centre Singapore 575628 Singapore
comment: The only vegan ice cream place in Singapore.The most important thing is that it taste delicious! I am lactose intolerant so their ice creams do me less harm.Now they have expanded into doing food like Pizzas and some cakes.The pizzas taste legit too so you might wanna give it a try. I find the taste pretty good as well. My vegan wife loves it!

address: 8 Sin Ming Road #01-03, Sin Ming Centre Singapore 575628 Singapore
comment: The Upper Thomson area has enjoyed popularity for offering  different F&B choices. Ice cream parlours are no strangers here, with Salted Caramel, Udders, NeLi and Scoopz within the shophouses. One of the earliest tenants of the area, Brownice, is located further inwards, within Sin Ming Centre, which specializes in ice cream made from all natural, egg-free and non-dairy products.Satisfying my waffle cravings, I ordered the Waffles with Peanut Butter Chocolate ($7.30; $3.80 for waffles, $3.50 for 1 scoop). The waffles is crisp on the outside and moist on the inside. The Peanut Butter Chocolate accompanying it, while trying to strike a balance between both flavours, tasted more chocolatey than the peanut butter taste.Anyone can enjoy the ice cream here without feeling guilty due to the nature of the contents. If you are around the Sin Ming / Upper Thomson area, this is one spot that should not be missed.

address: 8 Sin Ming Road #01-03, Sin Ming Centre Singapore 575628 Singapore
comment: Vegan food, vegan desserts and now......vegan ice cream. Brownice, a vegan ice cream parlor with a blue avatar, has kicked out a previous gourmet ice cream shop Ice Kimo at Sin Ming Centre. No dairy, no eggs, low fat, suitable for lactose-intolerant...These surely sounds like an attractive health contract. But the sweet treat is not necessarily a low-calorific indulgence. After all, unrefined sugar, nuts and brown rice are still usedTexture-wise, the ice-cream (two scoops for is not as smooth as most ice cream parlours including below320nitro. Luckily, both the Madagascar Vanilla and Cookies & Cream were not too sweet. Not too sure if coconut milk was used but there was an odd coconut aroma which lingers on.Don't mistake, I love coconut but perhaps I'll save it for other desserts.Constructed of French Chocolate, Hazelnut Chocolate ice cream and a raw crust, the tri-layer mudpie $9.80 refused to budge despite being left in room temperature for 20min. The ice cream flavours were more tolerable than the individual scoops earlier, and lovely contrasted with the salty biscuit base. The original toppings of caramelized salt almonds which ran out of stock, was a sign that they are likely to be tastier than our chocolate chips and granola. Due to the ingredients, the price of Brownice's vegan ice cream is not very nice. But perhaps its a good investment for our health.

address: 8 Sin Ming Road #01-03, Sin Ming Centre Singapore 575628 Singapore
comment: On my first trip to Brownice, I was a wee bit skeptical because of its dairy-free, vegan status.  And I was delightedly proven wrong. : )Their ice cream is really high-quality - good texture and natural-tasting flavours despite the lack of dairy and eggs.  I especially like the pumpkin-coconut flavour which is especially festive around this time of year.  In terms of range of flavours, Brownice is bit limited compared to the huge ice cream parlours because of the inherent restrictions that come when you take out dairy and eggs, but not to worry - they've still covered the greatest hits like chocolate, pistachio etc, and thanks to their high quality control it's really, really yummy.The staff there are lovely and willing to share recommendations and generally help customers out too.  Definitely worth checking out if you're in the Upper Thomson area.

address: 8 Sin Ming Road #01-03, Sin Ming Centre Singapore 575628 Singapore
comment: At Brownice, you can have your ice-cream without having to worry about counting your calories. Their ice-cream is low in fat and no eggs (not that I personally care, this is just for the vegans and those who are health-conscious)!I first heard of the brand when they opened a booth in a bazaar in school. I like bananas, so I got the banana oats then and found that the oats complemented the bananas pretty well. When my friends and I chanced upon this store, we got the ice-cream bowl to share. It consisted of four scoops of any ice-cream flavours and four toppings of our choice and only cost $12.50. It wasn't a bad deal - we sampled more flavours and the toppings gave us good value for money. The crunchy walnuts, plump raisins, tangy cranberries and caramelised almonds added more oomph to our dessert. If you plan to go down in a group, I recommend getting the ice-cream bowl since it's much cheaper than to buy individual ice-cream scoops.

address: 8 Sin Ming Road #01-03, Sin Ming Centre Singapore 575628 Singapore
comment: Where can a vegan get decent dessert in Singapore? Brownice is the much-awaited answer to that question.Serving up absolutely healthy ice-cream made from organic brown rice milk, fruits and nuts, they're dairy-free and vegan-friendly. Even non-vegans can give their healthy ice-cream range a shot - it honestly tastes just as good as "regular" ice cream.I like their ice-cream because I'm slightly lactose-intolerant so can't really stomach too milky ice-creams, so this is a good option. Their ice-cream pops (available at their store and vegtarian friendly outlets like Real Food) are my favourite, especially the Hazlenut Chocolate ($5.80).

I am so glad my friend told me about this hidden gem!!!! We took a cab here from Chinatown because we were not sure where it was, but it's actually a short walk from a subway station, so take the subway to save on transportation expenses.  We had the Hagrid's Afternoon Tea and I am so glad we ordered it!  Everything on the menu was delicious. I have to admit that I wasn't sure if the items would look exactly like it was on the menu because there are those places where the pictures in the menu are better then what you get and then there are those places where the pictures in the menu don't do them justice. Well, these pictures represented exactly what we received! This is a perfect place for any "true" fan. Yes I say true because I have read reviews on here where they say that their friend didn't realize it was a HP café. How are you a true fan and not notice this? Seriously!!!! From the menu, to the decorations, to the photo area, it all screams Harry Potter!!!!!  If you want to order the Hagrid's Afternoon Tea, keep in mind that it starts at 2pm and it's in limited quantities. Also, come with an appetite as it is a lot of food for 2 people. At least I think it's a lot of food. My husband had the seafood menu items, and he said they tasted really good. I had the non-seafood menu items and it was so delicious! All the desserts were amazing! Though I did order some coffee to counteract the sweetness of the desserts. Overall, a must for any HP fan that is visiting Singapore!

Harry Potter is my childhooood and coming to this place in all it's entirety I had a lot of expectations! I saw this place in one of the Facebook videos being shared. I had an opportunity to go to Singapore and went directly here to see what the hype was all about! Singapore is a great place by the way and I love the country and its great food! Now going back here, the decor was amazing and they have costumes and wands and broomsticks you can wear to take the coolest pictures and videos with their food! I remember while waiting for our food and drinks, my friends and I had battles with the wands haha. I ordered the famous drink that lights up when sprinkled with cinnamon. It was the coolest thing I've ever done. It was particularly of course my favorite part in the restaurant. The drink itself was good and let me tell you that it's an alcoholic drink. We ordered a lot of desserts since we ate from one of the hawk centers there. The food we got was why this place is only a three stars for me. I took out two because it was just not very good. I had so much expectations. I wanted it to be as magical in my mouth with the expensive price point. For one dish it was like $15-16 and so I was hoping it would be worth it. But it's not. This restaurant just needs better food and more people will flock here especially since it's Harry Potter, the business owners need to use that to their advantage and give their customers a more deserving magical and whimsical experience.

I was a little skeptical at first because it kind of sounded gimmicky, but we had such a good experience here. The food was absolutely delicious. My friends got breakfast food that they really enjoyed (side note: I'm pretty sure they put truffle oil in their eggs, so just keep that in mind in case you don't like truffle), while I got pasta with chicken and pesto. I was a little dismayed that they put lemon in it, as I personally do not like lemon at all, but it was still very good. The sauce was so creamy, and the plating was beautiful, as it was for the other meals. We also had a piece of chocolate cake that was amazing - it was rich, decadent, and moist. I split the cake with a friend, which was definitely a good idea because the food is quite filling here. One of my friends ordered Mr Lich's Flaming Brew, which was an alcoholic drink that they light on fire by sprinkling what I think was cinnamon onto it. It was definitely a cool sight, though I'm not sure how it tasted. I'm not really one to go all out with themes like this, but my friends convinced me to wear the robes they had for each of the houses in Harry Potter, and it ended up being a fun touch. Overall had a great time and would definitely recommend for a weekend brunch spot.

Located along 1094 Serangoon Road, lies a newly opened Harry Potter themed cafe. The moment you stepped in, you will be welcomed with brown decorated interior (brown chairs, brown wooden tables, brown wall tiles and etc...) that adds up to the theme. We asked for the signature drink and was told that it was on the menu, "Mr Lich's Brewing Brew" ($15). When served, it is a cup of neon blue colored drink that looks like magic portion, which is actually made up of lime juice and Curacao liqueur. A spoon full of Barcardi 151 Rum, was then torched by the server before pouring it into the mixture. You will be given cinnamon powder to sprinkle for the sparkling effects. Abracadabraaaa boom!We ordered the 2 cakes that taste as good as they looks! The Lychee Cake has a very nice fruity lychee flavor, very fluffy and not too sweet. The Chocolate Peanut Butter Cake is interesting good, with a complex flavorful the first spoonful.Tips: ~ Feel free to pick a few props from the side table when posing with your food and Goblet of Fire drink.  ~ They accept reservations, call them in advance as they get pretty booked for dinner and on weekends.[009/100]

This place is so adorable. We arrived pretty late at night and I was surprised to see diners dressed up in what appeared to be Harry Potter cosplay - but no, the cafe has outfits that you can wear to get in the spirit of things! The decor is so cute and very appropriately Hogwarts-like. Had I come in the daytime, I think the natural lighting would have made for some amazing pictures. We got the butterscotch ale, and though I've never been to the Wizarding World of Harry Potter, my friend who has said it tasted JUST like the butterbeer you can find there. It was delicious. The food was surprisingly good for a theme cafe. We got the confit chicken with pesto spaghetti and the pesto mayo pork ribs. Both were really well cooked, not too much pesto on either but enough to give you a could flavor. The pork ribs were super tender and the sides that came with it were delicious, very American-style like mashed potatoes and sweet corn. I loved it and that's coming from an American mashed potato addict. The witch's brew, although I didn't try it, seems like it's something you can't miss here. I was excited to see another diner get it, and the flaming drink looks exactly like a potion from Harry Potter. If I have one regret it's not trying that!

If not for the theme, my expectations would have been much lower. Food-wise the menu is the usual brunch and cafe fare with a twist. You can also play dress up with the ropes for Gryffindor, Slytherin, Ravenclaw and Hufflepuff. Interesting drinks as potions. It would have been better if the staff were more upbeat or dressed to fit the theme instead of just black tee shirts. Wouldn't mind coming back to try the dinner menu.

Very cute and quaint cafe with Harry Potter themed food and decor. I recommend this place is you have any leisure time to spare. We enjoyed this very cool and fun blue cocktail that went up in flames. It was also fun to dress up in robes & take some fun photos. It's bit off the beaten path so make sure to come if you have time to spare.

Such a cute theme! And yet, disappointing in execution.I came to Platform 1094 for the ever-famous cauldron drink and was thrilled to find a costume rack complete with robes, hats, wands and stuffed animals to complete the experience. This feature was the extent of the magical experience. While I loved the small touches, like the wooden stag chairs, the cauldron drink we received was less than impressive, beyond the sparks that fly when you dash it with cinnamon.It was great to visit once, but definitely won't be making a repeat appearance in my itinerary.

Being an incredibly huge Harry Potter fan, having a themed Harry Potter cafe really excited me. Unfortunately, I must admit that it was pretty underwhelming. For a themed cafe, I expected more; to see the theme being reflected in the food, the drinks, the decor, etc. Ambience wise, the only thing close to Harry Potter were the brick plastered walls... they had props, but there wasn't enough to go around (& also, they only had gryffindor robes :/). To give them credit, they did try to create "potions" which lit up, but again, that was only one drink (their signature)  Taste wise, everything was pretty standard; drinks needed more alcohol,

We are from out of town and had to come here since I'm a huge Harry Potter fan! I am only rating on the drinks as we did not try the food. Based on theme, it is really cutely Harry Potter. You cannot miss it- the corner had a whole wardrobe and some of the wall decor looks like ads out of Harry Potter. The drinks were mediocre at best and pricy. While the signature drink was clever and fun, it was weak. My husband had it because I don't like the taste of alcohol. However, when I drank it, it tasted like fruit juice that I think I could have handled it. I ordered a fruit smoothie (S$8), and I feel like I could have gotten 3 of these at the nearby food courts. Nothing memorable. Overall, I feel the experience and quality together rounds this place to a 3 stars
Very disappointing. For a theme cafe, the staffs are extremely low energy. Not interested at all to sell their products or make this a great experience.
A cute little Harry Potter themed restaurant close to Boon Keng MRT. Lots of interesting sounding dessert and drinks!Check out my visit: jamienan.com/2017/01/20/…

I am a Harry Potter super fan, and this place is so whimsical! Harry Potter's movie soundtrack is playing in the background, the walls are adorned with decor from the wizarding world, and the cleanliness is excellent. The menu is pretty good at providing an assortment of options; quinoa salad, crab pasta, duck, truffle fries, gorgeous desserts, and fun drinks (alcoholic and non-alcoholic). I can definitely feel the Harry Potter vibe in the menu selection, and I glad they didn't make it exactly like in the movies, I want food that I am actually able to eat lol. I love this place, and if I wasn't just here on vacation, I would be coming back here regularly!
